questions.question: Which of the following best defines the term 'Isomers'?
options: Molecules with the same molecular formula but different structural arrangements
Molecules with the same physical properties but different chemical formulas
Molecules that have the same mass but different elements
Molecules that contain the same number of double bonds only
questions.explanation: Isomers share the same count and type of atoms (molecular formula) but differ in how those atoms are connected or oriented in space.

questions.question: What type of isomerism is specifically characterized by a difference in the carbon skeleton, such as a straight chain versus a branched chain?
questions.explanation: Chain isomers (or skeletal isomers) occur when the carbon backbone is rearranged, such as butane and 2-methylpropane.

questions.question: Pentane and 2-methylbutane both have the molecular formula $\text{C}_{5}\text{H}_{12}$. These two molecules are examples of:
questions.explanation: Structural isomers have the same formula but different connectivity of atoms.

questions.question: Positional isomers differ by the location of a functional group or substituent. Which pair represents positional isomerism?
questions.explanation: Both have the formula $\text{C}_{3}\text{H}_{8}\text{O}$, but the hydroxyl group is on the first carbon in one and the second carbon in the other.

questions.question: Which type of isomerism exists between ethanol (an alcohol) and dimethyl ether (an ether)?
questions.explanation: Functional group isomers have the same molecular formula ($\text{C}_{2}\text{H}_{6}\text{O}$) but belong to different homologous series.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of carbon atoms required for an alkane to exhibit chain isomerism?
questions.explanation: Methane, ethane, and propane have only one possible arrangement. Butane ($\text{C}_{4}\text{H}_{10}$) is the first to have two isomers: n-butane and isobutane.

questions.question: Stereoisomers differ from structural isomers because they have:
options: The same connectivity but a different spatial orientation
A different number of carbon atoms
questions.explanation: Stereoisomers have atoms connected in the same order, but their orientation in three-dimensional space is different.

questions.question: Geometric isomerism (cis/trans) is most commonly found in which type of molecules?
options: Alkenes with restricted rotation around a double bond
questions.explanation: The $\pi$ bond in alkenes prevents free rotation, allowing for distinct 'cis' and 'trans' arrangements of substituents.

questions.question: How many structural isomers exist for the molecular formula $\text{C}_{4}\text{H}_{10}$?
questions.explanation: The two isomers are butane (straight chain) and 2-methylpropane (branched chain).

questions.question: Molecules that are non-superimposable mirror images of each other are called:
questions.explanation: Enantiomers are a type of optical isomerism occurring when a molecule has a chiral center, typically a carbon with four different groups attached.
